children.name: domination
children.definition: noun

children.name: power or control over other people or things
examples: _The film was about a group of robots set on world domination (= control of all countries) .

children.name: supervision
children.definition: noun
examples: when someone watches a person or activity and makes certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
_Students are not allowed to handle these chemicals unless they areunderthe supervisionofa teacher.

children.name: dominance
children.definition: noun
examples: _Music companies have profited from the dominance of CDs over vinyl records.

children.name: hand
children.definition: nounCONTROL

children.name: power
children.definition: the position of having political control of a country or government

children.name: be in power
examples: The law was passed when the Democrats were in power.

children.name: come to power
children.definition: start being in control
examples: Tony Blair came to power in 1997.

children.name: take power
children.definition: start being in control, usually without an election
examples: Many people fled after the military took power last September.

children.name: seize power
children.definition: take power by force
examples: His son seized power in a military coup.

children.name: assume powerformal
children.definition: take power
examples: He assumed power after the assassination of the former president.

children.name: win power
children.definition: win an election
examples: The Prime Minister is facing his toughest challenge since winning power.

children.name: rise to power
examples: The Roman emperor Vespasian rose to power through command of an army.

children.name: return/be returned to power
children.definition: start being in control again, usually after an election
examples: The party was returned to power with a reduced majority.

children.name: hold power
children.definition: be in power
examples: Economic disaster befell the country during the decade when he held power.

children.name: restore somebody to power
children.definition: put someone in control of a country again
examples: In 2004, the army restored him to power.

children.name: sweep to power
children.definition: win an election easily
examples: Reagan swept to power by promising reforms.

children.name: cling to power
children.definition: not lose it, or try not to lose it
examples: Mao Tse-tung, the leader of the 1949 Communist revolution, clung to power for 27 years.

children.name: sb’s rise to power
examples: The programme examines Saddam Hussein’s rise to power.

children.name: sb’s return to power
examples: Churchill’s return to power had an immediate effect upon Anglo-American relations.

children.name: in power
examples: The voters have once again shown their support for the party in power.

children.name: come/rise to power(= start having political control )
examples: De Gaulle came to power in 1958.
Theyseized powerin a military coup.

children.name: the ability to control people and events
power
children.definition: the ability or right to control people or events : quyền lực, quyền hành
examples: Do you think the police have too much power?
He was motivated by greed, envy, and the lust for power.
power over
People should have more power over the decisions that affect their lives.
have the power to do sth
Only Parliament has the power to make new laws.
power-mad/power-crazy/power-hungry(= wanting too much power )
power-hungry politicians
political/economic/military powercountries with little economic power

children.name: have power
examples: People who have power never seem to use it to help others.

children.name: get/gain power
examples: Women were trying to gain power in a male-dominated world.

children.name: use your power
children.definition: alsoexercise (your
examples: powerformal)The party will use all its power and influence to raise the issue in the Senate.|Questions have been asked about the way the police exercised their power.

children.name: wield powerformal
children.definition: use power - used when someone has a lot of power
examples: The Church still wields enormous power in the country.

children.name: great/huge/enormous
examples: The central banks have huge power.

children.name: limited
examples: The king's power was limited.

children.name: absolute power
children.definition: total power, with no limits
examples: Parents had absolute power over children in those days.

children.name: unbridled power
children.definition: without any controls
examples: Certain wealthy men exercised unbridled power.

children.name: real power
examples: The real power lay with the President’s advisers.

children.name: a power struggle
children.definition: a situation in which groups or leaders try to get control
examples: tranh dành quyền lựcThe country is locked in a power struggle between forces favouring and opposing change.

children.name: the balance of power
examples: There has been a shift in the balance of power between the two countries.

children.name: a position of power
children.definition: a job or role that gives someone power
examples: Many of them were using their positions of power for personal advantage.

children.name: an abuse of power
children.definition: a wrong or unfair use of power
examples: This cover-up is a scandalous abuse of power.

children.name: influence
children.definition: the power to affect the way someone or something develops, behaves, or thinks, without using direct force or orders : sức ảnh hưởng
examples: As a scientist, his influence was immense.
influence in
The Catholic Church has always had a lot of influence in Polish politics.
influence on/over
the unions’ influence over local politics
sb’s influence with somebodysomeone’s ability to persuade someone else to do things:ảnh hưởng của ai với ai
Using her influence with her husband, Evita Peron won women the right to vote.

children.name: have an influence on somebody/something
examples: His works have had an influence on many modern writers.

children.name: exert an influenceformal
children.definition: have an influence
examples: Technology exerts a powerful influence over our lives.

children.name: use your influence
examples: She wasn’t afraid to use her influence to get what she wanted.

children.name: exercise/wield influenceformal
children.definition: use it
examples: The Federal Reserve exercises influence on the economy by setting short-term interest rates.

children.name: come/fall under the influence of somebody/something
children.definition: be influenced by someone or something
examples: They had come under the influence of a religious sect.

children.name: extend your influence
children.definition: make your influence larger
examples: Syria had the opportunity to extend its influence in the region.

children.name: a good/positive influence
examples: Television can have a positive influence on young people.

children.name: a bad/negative influence
examples: He thought her friends were a bad influence.

children.name: a big/great influence
examples: The goalkeeper’s injury had a big influence on the match.

children.name: an important/significant/major influence
examples: Parents have an important influence on children's development.|He was a major influence on my musical tastes.

children.name: considerable influence
examples: Well-organized pressure groups can exert considerable influence on the government.

children.name: a strong/powerful influence
examples: The press can have a powerful influence on the way people vote.

children.name: a deep/profound influence
examples: His writings had a profound influence on the Romantic poets.

children.name: a growing influence
examples: Many people are worried about the growing influence of these websites.

children.name: a lasting influence
children.definition: continuing for a long time
examples: His travels in Africa had a lasting influence on his work.

children.name: a direct/indirect influence
examples: The Cubist painters had a direct influence on his work.|The federal government has an indirect influence on investment through its control of bank credits.

children.name: a calming/soothing influence
examples: The music seemed to have a calming influence.

children.name: sb’s personal influence
examples: Frank used his personal influence to get his son a job at the newspaper.

children.name: political/cultural/economic influence
examples: French political influence began to dominate the country.

children.name: outside/external influence
children.definition: happening from outside a country or a situation
examples: They must make their own decisions, free from external influence.|The US remains the biggest outside influence on the country.

children.name: undue influence
children.definition: too much influence
examples: He felt that the United States wielded undue influence in Europe.

children.name: authority
children.definition: the right to make decisions and control people, which a person has because of their job or official position: quyền lực
examples: No one dared to question the principal’s authority.

children.name: have authority
examples: Teachers should have the authority to discipline their students.|He has no authority over us anymore.

children.name: exercise/exert your authority
children.definition: alsowield authorityformal
examples: (= use your authority )In practice it’s very difficult for the president to exercise his authority.|He was one of those people who want to wield authority over others.

children.name: abuse/misuse your authority
children.definition: use your authority in a bad way
examples: The mayor was accused of abusing his authority and taking bribes.

children.name: establish/assert/impose/stamp your authority
children.definition: show people that you have authority
examples: The new manager was anxious to establish her authority.|Robertson quickly stamped his authority on the team.|The State Department pressed him to take bolder steps to assert his authority.

children.name: lose your authority
examples: He’s worried that he is losing his authority over the party.

children.name: undermine/weaken sb’s authority
children.definition: make someone’s authority weaker
examples: I wasn’t trying to undermine your authority.

children.name: exceed/overstep your authority
children.definition: do more than you have the power or right to do
examples: A higher court decided that the judge had exceeded his authority.

children.name: challenge sb’s authority
children.definition: try to take the power away from someone
examples: There had been no-one to really challenge his authority.

children.name: full/complete/total authority
examples: The manager has full authority to make decisions.

children.name: absolute authority
children.definition: complete authority over everyone – used especially about the leader of a country
examples: In those days, the emperor had absolute authority.

children.name: parental authority
examples: The younger children are more likely to resist parental authority.

children.name: governmental authority
examples: Their failure undermined governmental authority.

children.name: presidential authority
examples: A number of constitutional amendments have increased presidential authority.

children.name: legal authority
examples: US agents have legal authority to bring criminals back from overseas.

children.name: be in a position of authority
examples: I’ve never been in a position of authority before.

children.name: have an air of authorityapproving
children.definition: look like you have authority, in a way that makes people obey you
examples: The commander had an unmistakeable air of authority.

children.name: a challenge to sb’s authority
examples: The leadership saw the demonstrations as a challenge to their authority.

children.name: an authority figure
children.definition: someone, such as a parent or teacher, who has the power to tell young people what they can do
examples: The teacher is an authority figure, like the parent.

children.name: the authority to do something
examples: Only the president has the authority to declare war.

children.name: authority over
examples: Several countries claim authority over the islands.

children.name: in authority
examples: I need to speak to someone in authority(= who has a position of power ).

children.name: have a say
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈseɪ/  the right to give your opinion about a decision, so that you have some power to influence it: có tiếng nói
examples: ▪ If we’re going to undertake such a big project, the voters should have a say.

children.name: have a say in
examples: ▪ By giving the workers a greater say in the running of the company, we hope to increase cooperation and job satisfaction.

children.name: have the final sayhave the power to make the final decision: Quyêt định
examples: ▪ The Prisoner Review Board can recommend that a prisoner is released, but Illinois Gov. Jim Edgar has the final say.

children.name: muscle
children.definition: /ˈmʌsəl/  power that sb has because of their money, political position, or strength, and which makes it possible for them to do things that other people or organizations cannot do: sức mạnh, thế lực
examples: ▪ The government has for years been trying to destroy the muscle of the trade unions
have the muscle to do something
▪ Hanson Trust has the muscle to buy up some of America’s biggest companies.
military/financial/political etc muscle
▪ The Republicans do not have the political muscle to prevent the treaty being rejected by Congress.

children.name: clout
children.definition: informal the power that you have to influence other people’s decisions, especially because you can use your position or your knowledge to persuade people in authority to do what you want: quyền lực, tầm ảnh hưởng, “đinh đầu to”

children.name: have/carry clout
examples: ▪ The banks do not carry quite as much clout as they used to.

children.name: political/financial etc clout
examples: ▪ Doctors have considerably more political clout than teachers.

children.name: jurisdiction
children.definition: the power that a government, court, or organization has to make laws or to decide whether people are breaking the law - use this especially when you talk about the limits of this power: thẩm quyền
examples: ▪ In general, the American courts have no jurisdiction to deal with crimes outside the USA.
▪ The Air Transit Authority’s jurisdiction extends beyond the airport itself to include warehouses and associated buildings
jurisdiction over
▪ The council has no jurisdiction over these matters.
have jurisdictionover
The committeehas jurisdictionover all tax measures.
be within/under somebody’s jurisdiction
It’s not within our jurisdiction to tell people what to do in the privacy of their own homes.
be outside somebody’s jurisdiction
The courts said the claim raised ‘political questions’ that were outside its jurisdiction.

children.name: powerful
children.definition: /ˈpaʊəʳfəl/  apowerfulperson, organization, or country has a lot of power, and can control people and influence events: đầy quyền lực
examples: ▪ Parliament had become more powerful than the King.
▪ one of the most powerful men in US politics
▪ Berlusconi was the owner of a powerful media empire.
He was one of the most powerful men in Bohemia.
a very influential and powerful family
rich and powerful nations

children.name: influential
children.definition: having a lot of influence and therefore changing the way people think and behave : có tầm ảnh hưởng, có sức ảnh hưởng
examples: Her uncle is a rich and influential businessman.
She is probably the most influential member of the finance committee.

children.name: an influential film critic
examples: He had influential friends.

children.name: influential in
examples: Dewey was influential in shaping economic policy.

children.name: highly influentialvery influential
examples: Galbraith was a highly influential writer on economic affairs.

children.name: strong
children.definition: powerful - use this about apoliticalgroupthat is supported by a lot of people: mạnh
examples: There has been a strong anti-nuclear movement in Japan for many years.
The communists were particularly strong in the big industrial cities.
He is a strong voice in the state assembly.

children.name: dominant
children.definition: more powerful than other people, groups, countries etc: chi phối, “át, trội”

children.name: Gradually, Microsoft became the dominant company in the software business
examples: At the time Portugal was the dominant naval power in the Mediterranean.
She was the dominant force in women’s tennis for many years.
The company has a dominant position in the market.

children.name: all-powerful
children.definition: having more power than anyone else, especially when this is not fair: toàn quyền
examples: The all-powerful central committee meets twice a year.

children.name: Catherine the Great, the all-powerful ruler of the Russian Empire
examples: Hollywood stars of the 30s were in awe of the all-powerful studio bosses.

children.name: have friends in high places
children.definition: to have power or influence because you know people who have very important jobs and positions and who will help you if necessary:
examples: ▪ Bowen had friends in high places, and managed to raise large sums of money from the Carnegie and Rockefeller Foundations.

children.name: ▪ The Achym family had friends in high places, including the powerful Lord Burghley, and were allowed to return
powerless
children.definition: /ˈpaʊəʳləs/  someone who ispowerlesshas no power to control or influence what happens: không có quyền, bất lực
examples: ▪ Blocked by the Democrats in the Senate, Bush appeared powerless.
powerless against
▪ The people of Hungary were powerless against the tanks of the Red Army
powerless to do something
▪ The UN was powerless to prevent the war spreading.

children.name: weak
children.definition: /wiːk/  someone who is weak does not have much power because they cannot make other people respect them or obey them: yếu kém
examples: ▪ These policies failed because the government was weak and ineffective.
▪ a weak, indecisive principal
weakness[uncountable noun]: Sự yếu kém
▪ The King’s mercy towards the rebels was regarded as a sign of weakness.

children.name: have no say
children.definition: /hæv ˌnəʊ ˈseɪ/  to have no power to influence what happens because your opinion is ignored or regarded as unimportant:: không có tiêng nói
examples: ▪ Whenever we have to make an important decision, I feel that I have no say.

children.name: have no say in something
examples: ▪ The French government allows the Annamese almost no say at all in running their affairs.

children.name: come to power
children.definition: /ˌkʌm tə ˈpaʊəʳ/  to take political control of a country, especially by being elected:

children.name: lên nắm quyền
examples: ▪ When Mrs Thatcher came to power in 1979, no one expected her to stay there for 13 years.
Khi Bà Thatcher lên cầm quyền vào năm 1979, không ai muốn bà ấy tiếp ục trong vòng 13 năm nữa.
▪ After coming to power, President Clinton tried to resolve the conflict.

children.name: Saiu khi nắm quyền, tổng thông Clinton cố gắng giải những mau thuẩn
take office U
children.definition: take office/ˌteɪk ˈɒfsǁ-ˈɔːf-/  if a person or political party takes office, they start working in an official position of power or take political control of a country:: nhận chức
examples: ▪ Less than three weeks after Labour took office, an economic crisis developed.

children.name: Ít hơn ba tuần sau khi Labour nhận chức thì sự suy thoái knh tế phát triển
examples: ▪ When Olson took office in January 1939, he was the state’s first Democratic governor in forty years.

children.name: Khi Olson nhận chức vào năm 19939, anh ấy là chinh quyền dân chủ đầu tiên trong 40 năm
take power
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ˈpaʊəʳ/  to get control of a country through violence:: Nắm quyền
examples: ▪ The Bolsheviks took power in 1917.
▪ General da Souza had the intention of taking power through a coup d'etat.

children.name: seize power
children.definition: /ˌsiːz ˈpaʊəʳ/  to get control of a country suddenly or quickly, by using military force: gianh chính quyền
examples: ▪ Communist forces had come out in an attempt to seize power.
▪ The Czar was overthrown when the revolutionaries seized power.

children.name: take over
children.definition: /ˌteɪk ˈəʊvəʳ/  to take power from an existing government or organization by using military force: Đảm nhiệm
examples: ▪ A revolutionary government took over, featuring a reorganized council.

children.name: Chính phủ cách mạng đảm nhiệm việc tổ chức hội đồng
examples: ▪ The authorities began to make the necessary arrangements for taking over the garrisons, which were still in the hands of the enemy.

children.name: Chính quyền đã bắt đầu thưc hiejeenj những biện pháp để đảm nhiệm các binh lính vẫn còn trong tay kẻ thù
